Japan Received 9 May 1996; revised 10 July 1996; accepted 10 JuLy 1996 Abstract A series of mixed metal oxides of the compositions CaI _,SrxTiI _yNiyO (x = 0-1.0, y = 0- 1.0) were prepared by the citrate method, and was tested for the oxidation of CH4 to synthesis gas. Analytical results clearly showed the presence of Ca1 - x SrxTi i - y Ni ~.O perovskite structure, where Sr substituted all the Ca sites while Ni substituted the Ti sites in the range of y < 0.1. Among the catalysts tested, the compositions of x = y = 0.2 showed the highest activity. Either Ni species in the Ca0.8Sro.2Til_yNiyO perovskite structure or NiO originally separated from the perovskite structure during the preparation was in situ reduced to Ni metal during the CH4 oxidation. The Ni metal thus formed showed high activity for synthesis gas production, where Cao.sSro.2TiO3 perovskite has an important role as a cartier of the Ni catalyst. Three catalysts of the composition Cao.sSr0.2Til.oNi0.~O were then prepared by citrate, impregnation and mixing methods. The highest activity was obtained with the citrate, followed by the impregnation of Ni on Cao.sSr0.2TiO3 perovskite. The catalyst prepared by the mixing method afforded no perovskite, resulting in low activity. The amount of coke formation over the Ni catalysts after the reaction for 150 h was as follows: citrate < impregnation << Ni/y-A1203 as the comparison. Ca0.sSr0.2TiO3 perovskite was effective as the cartier of the Ni catalyst for the partial oxidation of CH4 to synthesis gas. Ni/Cao.8Sro.2TiO3 prepared by the citrate method is the most sustainable against coke formation during the reaction. It is likely that the citrate method gave * Corresponding author. Keywords: Perovskite oxides; (Ca,Sr)TiO3; Ni; Citrate method; CH4 oxidation; Synthesis gas 1. Introduction The partial oxidation of CH4 to synthesis gas is an established industrial process [1] which operates at high temperatures (> 1200) and high pressures (150 atm). Recently, an intensive study has been carried out on the catalytic partial oxidation of CH4 to synthesis gas [2-14]. This process has advantages over the conventional steam reforming of CH4 to make synthesis gas, as the latter process is highly endothermic and produces synthesis gas having a H2/CO ratio ~> 3. The partial oxidation of CH4, expected to afford synthesis gas having an H2/CO ratio of about 2, makes methanol synthesis an ideal follow-up process. Ashcroft and co-workers [2-4] reported that transition met- als, Ni, Ru, Rh, Pd, Ir, and Pt supported on alumina were active in this reaction at temperatures of 775. Schmidt and co-workers [5-7] reported that platinum and rhodium surfaces in a metal-coated ceramic monolith afforded mostly U2 and CO with almost complete conversion of CH4 and 02 at a short residence time. Some transition metal oxides combined with alkaline earth or rare earth oxides, i.e. CoO-MgO, NiO-CaO, CoO-Yb203, or Ni/Yb203 were interest- ingly found to be active as the catalyst at low temperatures ( ~< 700, down to 300) and extremely high space velocities in the partial oxidation of CH4 to synthesis gas [8-11], but hot spots have been observed in the catalyst bed where the actual temperature was 300-850 higher than that reported [12-14]. Ni/A1203, a typical catalyst for the steam reforming, was studied for the partial oxidation of CH4 at temperatures > 700 [15]. This process was thought to involve first the oxidation of a part of CH4 to H20 and CO2, followed by the reforming reactions of CH4 with H20 and CO2. In the steam reforming of CH4 to synthesis gas, deactivation of supported metal catalysts by coke formation is a serious problem caused by fouling of the metal surface, blockage of catalyst pores and voids, and/or actual physical disintegration of the catalyst support [16]. Actually, in the industrial process, a large amount of steam was added in order to avoid coke formation. In the partial oxidation of CH4 to synthesis gas, coke formation over the catalyst frequently takes place, resulting in catalyst deactivation. Coke formation has been fre- quently ignored in the literature [2-15], except in the case of Claridge et al. [17], who observed that the relative rate of coke formation follows the order Ni > Pd >> Rh, Ru, Pt, Ir. Nickel catalysts are highly effective for partial oxidation of methane to synthesis gas, but they are unsatisfactory with respect to coke formation. Audier et al. [ 18] clearly demonstrated that a significant amount of coke can be formed over the catalysts containing iron or nickel. High T. Hayakawa et al. /Applied Catalysis A: General 149 (1997) 391-410 393 dispersion of metal species over catalyst may reduce coke formation [16]. Slagtern and Olsbye [19] reported the in situ formation and high activity of metal species for synthesis gas production in LaMO3 (M = Rh, Ni or Co) perovskite system, where the perovskite structure decomposed during the reac- tion. The best system, LaRhO3, kept high activity for 120 h on stream at 800 and showed high dispersion of Rh metal, while both LaNiO3 and LaCoO3 were deactivated probably due to coke formation during the reaction. We have briefly reported the activity of Ca 1 - x SrxTi 1 -- y Ni yO in the oxidation of CH 4 to synthesis gas, where the Ni catalyst was prepared by the citrate method followed by the in situ reduction of perovskite-like precursors [20,21]. It is likely that Ca1 , SrxTiO3 perovskite and the citrate method are important for the sustainability of the Ni catalyst against coke formation [22]. From the industrial point of view, Ni is preferable as the active species compared to expensive precious metal such as Rh or Ru. This paper deals with the details of the activity of the (Ca, Sr)(Ti, Ni)O catalyst and its sustainability against coke formation in the partial oxida- tion of CH4 to synthesis gas. 2. Experimental The catalysts Cal_xSrxTil_yNiyO (x = 0-1.0 and y = 0-1.0) were prepared by the citrate method [23] as follows: an aqueous solution of reagent grade nickel nitrate, alkaline earth carbonates and titanium isopropoxide was treated with an excess amount of citric acid and ethylene glycol, evaporated at 80-90 to make a sol of organic metal complex. This was followed by two-step decomposition by heating at 200 for 5 h and 500 for 5 h, and finally calcination at 850 in air for 10 h. Moreover, three catalysts of the composition Ca0.8Sro2Ti~.oNi0.20 were prepared by citrate, impregnation and mixing meth- ods. The impregnation method for preparing Ni/Cao.sSro.zTiO3 was carried out as follows: the calculated amount of aqueous nickel nitrate was treated with an equimolar amount of citric acid and ethylene glycol, evaporated at 80-90 to make a viscous liquid, and then diluted with distilled water. The solution was then added into a suspension of the Ca0.sSro.zTiO3 perovskite in distilled water, which was previously prepared by the citrate method. The suspension was again evaporated at 80-90, and calcined at 850 in air for 5 h. The mixing method for preparing the mixed metal oxide was carried out by grinding a mixture of metal oxides followed by calcination at 850 or 1100 in air for 5 h. The catalysts are shown as Ni/Ca0.sSro.2TiO3 (cit.), Ni/Cao.sSro.zTiO3 (imp.) and Ca0.sSr0.2Til.0Ni0.20 (mix.) for citrate, impregnation and mixing, respectively. The Ni/y-A1203 catalyst, used for comparison, was prepared by the impregna- tion method as follows: the calculated amount of aqueous nickel nitrate was treated with an equimolar amount of citric acid and ethylene glycol, evaporated at 80-90 to make a viscous liquid, and then diluted with distilled water. The 394 T. Hayakawa et al. /Applied Catalysis A: General 149 (1997) 391-410 solution was then added into a suspension of "y-A1203 (Sumitomo, NK-124). The suspension was again evaporated at 80-90, and calcined at 850 in air for 5 h. The amount of Ni was 11.5 wt.-% on T-AlzO3. The structure of the catalysts thus prepared was studied as follows: the powder X-ray diffraction patterns (XRD) were recorded using MXP-18 (MAC) with Cu K ce radiation. X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were obtained with a PHI-5000 spectrometer employing Mg Ka radiation (1253.6 eV) and an electron flood gun to provide charge neutralization of the non conducting samples. The surface area of the catalysts were measured by the BET method with a Micromeritics model 2200. Cal_~Sr~Ti0.8Ni0.20 showed a surface area between 0.7 and 8.3 m2/g, increasing with increase in the Sr content. Both Ca0.8Sr0.2Til_vNiyO and Ca0.sSr0.2Til.0Ni0.20 showed almost the same value at 1 m2/g. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM; Hitachi S-800) was used to study the overall microstructure of the catalyst particles. Transmission electron mi- croscopy (TEM; JEOL, JEM-2000FXII) was undertaken to study the microstruc- ture on a fine scale and identify coke formation over the catalyst. Analyses using energy dispersion spectroscopy (EDS, Phillips DX-4) were carried out by fixing a probe diameter at 1.0 nm. All the catalysts have been tested by using temperature programmed reaction (TPR) in a mixture of air (2.4 l/h) and CH4 (1.0 I/h, from Takachiho). The TPR was carried out by increasing the reaction temperature from room tempera- ture to 800 at the rate of 2.5/min. Moreover, the reactions for testing the catalyst life were carried out at 800 for 150 h under the same conditions. A U-shaped quartz reactor was used, with the catalyst bed near the bottom. 300 mg of catalyst was dispersed in 2 ml of quartz wool to avoid sintering and clogging of the reactor. The thermocouple was introduced at the top of the reactor, and placed in the middle of the catalyst bed. The produced gases were sampled immediately after the reactor and injected into a gas chromatograph for analysis. The selectivities to C2 compounds, CO2, CO and H2 were calculated based on the numbers of carbon and hydrogen atoms in CH4. 3. Results and discussion 3.1. After the reaction, peaks of Ni metal appeared instead of the weakening of NiO peaks, suggesting a substantial reduction of NiO to Ni metal during the reaction. No change in the peaks of Ca0.8Sr0.2TiO3 suggests that the perovskite was stable during the reaction; only NiO was reduced to Ni metal. XRD analyses of Cal_xSrxTi0.8Ni0.20 clearly showed the peaks of NiO together with Cal_~SrxTiO3 perovskite: NiO was again separated from the perovskite structure (Fig. 2). Weak peaks of CaO (JCPDS: 37-1497) were also observed at a high concentration of Ca, while SrO was not detected even in SrTi0.8Nio.20. This may be due to an enhanced substitution of Ni for the Ti site in the Sr-rich perovskite since SrTiO3 possesses a highly stable structure. The crystal structure of CaTiO3 is orthorhombic [26], while SrTiO3 has a cubic structure which is the most symmetric and contains one formula unit per cell [27]. The peaks of the Cal_~SrxTiO3 perovskite were sharpened and shifted towards lower 2 0 angle, i.e., a higher d value, almost obeying the Vegard's law when x increased, due to the structure transition from orthorhombic CaTiO3 to cubic SrTiO3 without an intermediate tetragonal phase [24,27]. 3.2. After the reduction with CH4 (1.0 l/h) for 2 h at 800, the activity of the catalyst (y = 0.2) for synthesis gas formation was unchanged (Table 1). The catalyst (y = 0.4) showed similar results to that (y = 0.2). When the Ni content was low, i.e., y = 0-0.025, synthesis gas was not formed even after the catalysts were treated with CH4. It is likely that Ni species substituted for Ti site in the perovskite structure cannot be reduced easily and showed no activity for the reforming reaction. Only the catalyst with (y = 0.05) showed a substantial increase in the activity for synthesis gas formation after reduction with CH4. The selectivity to synthesis gas increased with increasing Ni content and reached an almost constant value at y >~ 0.2. Thus, it is likely that the active species for the synthesis gas formation is Ni metal formed by the reduction of NiO, which is separated from the perovskite structure. The ratio of Ni/Ti was hereafter fixed at 0.2/0.8. Cao.sSro.2Tio.8Nio.20 for synthesis gas formation suddenly appeared when the reaction temperature reached 800 (Fig. 4). The other Cat_xSrxTi0.sNi0.20 catalyst did not produce synthesis gas, but substantially catalyzed CH4 combus- tion just after the reaction temperature reached 800. In these cases, a reaction time of 10-30 min at 800 was required for modifying the catalyst suitable for synthesis gas formation (Table 2). Therefore, an easier reduction of NiO to Ni metal may occur in Cao.8Sro.2Tio.8Nio.20 compared to the other Cal_xSrxTio.sNio.20 catalysts. It was thus found that the Ni catalyst prepared from Cao.8Sro.2Tio.8Nio.2O showed the highest activity for synthesis gas forma- tion from CH4. 3.3. Structures of the Ni catalysts prepared by three different methods The Cao.sSro.2Tio.8Nio.20 was a mixture of CaO, Cao.sSro.2TiO3 and NiO (Figs. 1 and 2). CaO is frequently used for the oxidative coupling of CH4 [28] and can reasonably affect the CH4 oxidation results. In order to get a more precise view of the Ni catalyst by simplifying the system, the Cao.sSro.2Til.0Nio.20 composition has been chosen considering the stoichiom- etry of Cao.sSro.2TiO3 perovskite in the catalyst preparation. To confirm the effect of the perovskite structure, Cao.sSro.2Til.0Nio.20 catalysts were prepared by three different methods, i.e., citrate, impregnation and mixing methods, and are shown as Ni/Cao.8Sro.2TiO3 (cit.), Ni/Cao.sSro.2TiO3 (imp.) and Cao.sSro.2Ti ~.oNio.20 (mix.), respectively. In the mixing method, two calcination temperatures, 850 for 5 h and 1100 for 5 h, were applied in order to check the effect of growth of the perovskite structure during the calcination. Moreover, tiny dark spots were observed in the field of the oval-shaped single crystal of the perovskite (Fig. 16c), suggesting the formation of finely dispersed Ni metal over the Ni/Cao.sSro.2TiO3 (cit.) catalyst. The citrate method thus gave high dispersion of Ni species over the Cao.8Sro.2TiO3 perovskite containing Ni species in the structure, resulting in a strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) between Ni and the perovskite. This reflects the XPS observation of the high surface content of Ni species over the Ni/Cao.8Sro.2TiO3 (cit.) among the catalysts used, suggesting that the Ni species has a high dispersion over the catalyst surface. The easy reduction of Ni species over the Ni/Cao.sSro.2TiO3 (cit.) compared to that over the Ni/Cao.8Sro.2TiO3 (imp.) mentioned previously also suggests the presence of finer particles of Ni over the Ni/Cao.8Sro.2TiO3 (cit.). It is likely that both the high Ni dispersion and the SMSI contribute to the high activity as well as the high sustainability of the catalyst. As previously mentioned in the CH4 oxidation over Ni/A1203 catalyst [15], the present process is also thought to involve first the oxidation of part of CH4 to H20 and CO2, followed by the reforming reaction of CH4 with H20 and CO2. Therefore, the catalyst bed may be composed of two zones, the first zone is composed of NiO over the perovskite or Ni in the perovskite under the oxygen-rich atmosphere and the second is of Ni metal under the reducing atmosphere. Coke formation reasonably takes place over the Ni metal surface of the second zone and its rate strongly depends on the carrier of the Ni metal catalyst. It has been demonstrated that the Ni catalysts supported on (Ca,Sr)TiO3 are active for the cn4 oxidation to synthesis gas, among which the Ni/Cao.8Sro.2TiO3 (cit.) prepared by the citrate method from the perovskite precursor was the most effective. Coke formation over the Ni/Cao.8Sro.zTiO3 (cit.) was negligible, even after the reaction for 150 h, and this is important since Ni is abundant and cheap, and can be used in place of the expensive platinum group metals. 4. Conclusion A series of Cal_xSrxTil_yNiyO perovskite catalysts was prepared by the citrate method and used in the oxidation of CH4. In the series of Ca o.8Sro.2Til_ y NiyO, the catalysts containing Ni (y >~ 0. l) showed high activity for CH4 combustion around 600, which suddenly changed to synthesis gas T. Hayakawa et al. / Applied Catalysis A: General 149 (1997) 391-410 4(/9 formation at 800. In the case of Cal_xSrxTi0.sNi0.20, an increase in x resulted in a high activity for the CH4 combustion, and the highest selectivity to synthesis gas at 800 was obtained with the catalyst of x = 0.2. Under the conditions of synthesis gas formation, the catalyst bed was composed of two zones: the first catalyzed CH4 combustion under the oxygen-rich atmosphere and the second catalyzed CH4 reforming with H20 and CO2 under the oxygen-deficient atmosphere. Among the catalysts tested, Cao.sSro.2Tio.sNio.20 showed the highest selectivity for the synthesis gas formation. Either Ni species in the perovskite structure or NiO originally separated from the perovskite structure during the catalyst preparation was easily reduced to Ni metal under the oxygen-deficient atmosphere at high temperature, and the Ni metal thus formed in the second zone showed high activity for synthesis gas formation. The Ni catalyst prepared by impregnation over Cao.sSro.2TiO3 perovskite carrier showed activity, while that prepared by mixing and calcining metal oxides contained no perovskite structure and showed no activity. The Ni/y- A1203 catalyst used for comparison showed activity, but significant coke formation occurred resulting in the deactivation. In situ prepared Ni catalyst from the composition Cao.sSro.2Til.0Nio.2O showed no coke formation and the highest activity among the catalysts tested. It is thus likely that the Cao.sSro.2TiO3 perovskite structure has an important role as the carrier of the Ni catalyst for synthesis gas formation. Both the high sustainability and the high activity of the in situ prepared Ni catalyst may be due to the high Ni dispersion and a strong metal-support interaction between Ni and the Cao.sSro.2TiO3 perovskite. The high Ni dispersion can be formed by the following two possible mechanisms: ( 1 ) Ni included originally in the perovskite lattice is released together with St/Ca during the preparation, or (2) NiO originally separated from the perovskite structure can be reduced to Ni in the presence of Sr/Ca during the reaction. The composition of Cao.sSro.2TiO3 as the carrier may also have a certain importance from the point of view of structure transition from orthorhombic unit cell to cubic unit cell, thereby affecting the catalytic activity in the CH4 oxidation. Tel.: (+81-298) 54-4450; fax: (+81-298) 54-4709 A series of mixed metal oxides of the compositions Ca1−x Sr x Ti1−y Ni y O (x = 0–1.0, y = 0–1.0) were prepared by the citrate method, and was tested for the oxidation of CH4 to synthesis gas. Analytical results clearly showed the presence of Ca1−x Sr x Ti1−y Ni y O perovskite structure, where Sr substituted all the Ca sites while Ni substituted the Ti sites in the range of y < 0.1. Among the catalysts tested, the compositions of x = y = 0.2 showed the highest activity. Either Ni species in the Ca0.8Sr0.2Ti1−y Ni y O perovskite structure or NiO originally separated from the perovskite structure during the preparation was in situ reduced to Ni metal during the CH4 oxidation. The Ni metal thus formed showed high activity for synthesis gas production, where Ca0.8Sr0.2TiO3 perovskite has an important role as a carrier of the Ni catalyst. Three catalysts of the composition Ca0.8Sr0.2Ti1.0Ni0.2O were then prepared by citrate, impregnation and mixing methods. The highest activity was obtained with the citrate, followed by the impregnation of Ni on Ca0.8Sr0.2TiO3 perovskite. The catalyst prepared by the mixing method afforded no perovskite, resulting in low activity. The amount of coke formation over the Ni catalysts after the reaction for 150 h was as follows: citrate < impregnation ⪡ Ni γ-Al2O3 as the comparison. Ca0.8Sr0.2TiO3 perovskite was effective as the carrier of the Ni catalyst for the partial oxidation of CH4 to synthesis gas. Ni/Ca0.8Sr0.2TiO3 prepared by the citrate method is the most sustainable against coke formation during the reaction. It is likely that the citrate method gave high Ni dispersion over the perovskite as well as strong metal-support interaction between Ni and the perovskite, resulting in both high activity and high sustainability against coke formation. coredata.dc:description: A series of mixed metal oxides of the compositions Ca1−x Sr x Ti1−y Ni y O (x = 0–1.0, y = 0–1.0) were prepared by the citrate method, and was tested for the oxidation of CH4 to synthesis gas. Analytical results clearly showed the presence of Ca1−x Sr x Ti1−y Ni y O perovskite structure, where Sr substituted all the Ca sites while Ni substituted the Ti sites in the range of y < 0.1. Among the catalysts tested, the compositions of x = y = 0.2 showed the highest activity. Either Ni species in the Ca0.8Sr0.2Ti1−y Ni y O perovskite structure or NiO originally separated from the perovskite structure during the preparation was in situ reduced to Ni metal during the CH4 oxidation. The Ni metal thus formed showed high activity for synthesis gas production, where Ca0.8Sr0.2TiO3 perovskite has an important role as a carrier of the Ni catalyst. Three catalysts of the composition Ca0.8Sr0.2Ti1.0Ni0.2O were then prepared by citrate, impregnation and mixing methods. The highest activity was obtained with the citrate, followed by the impregnation of Ni on Ca0.8Sr0.2TiO3 perovskite. The catalyst prepared by the mixing method afforded no perovskite, resulting in low activity. The amount of coke formation over the Ni catalysts after the reaction for 150 h was as follows: citrate < impregnation ⪡ Ni γ-Al2O3 as the comparison. Ca0.8Sr0.2TiO3 perovskite was effective as the carrier of the Ni catalyst for the partial oxidation of CH4 to synthesis gas. Ni/Ca0.8Sr0.2TiO3 prepared by the citrate method is the most sustainable against coke formation during the reaction. It is likely that the citrate method gave high Ni dispersion over the perovskite as well as strong metal-support interaction between Ni and the perovskite, resulting in both high activity and high sustainability against coke formation.
coredata.dc:title: Sustainable Ni/Ca1−xSrxTiO3 catalyst prepared in situ for the partial oxidation of methane to synthesis gas
